questions.question: Match the following components of a nerve with their corresponding structures: 1. Endoneurium a. Surrounds nerve 2. Perineurium b. Surrounds axons 3. Epineurium c. Surrounds fascicles
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a Explanation : 1.Endoneurium b. Surrounds axons 2. Perineurium c. Surrounds fascicles 3. Epineurium a. Surrounds nerve Structure of Nerve: Neuron (Nerve Cell): The basic structural and functional unit of the nervous system, consisting of a cell body, dendrites, and an axon. Axon : A long projection from the neuron that carries electrical impulses away from the cell body.The basic unit of nerve Endoneurium : A delicate connective tissue that surrounds individual axons within a nerve. Fascicle : A bundle of axons grouped together, surrounded by the perineurium. Perineurium : A protective sheath of connective tissue that encases each fascicle within the nerve. Epineurium : The outermost layer of dense connective tissue that surrounds the entire nerve, protecting the bundled fascicles. 2 types of nerves: Spinal nerves- 31 pairs Cranial nerves- 12 pairs 2 roots of Spinal nerves: Anterior- Motor fibres Posterior- Sensory fibres

questions.question: What is the approximate rate of axon regeneration in the peripheral nervous system (PNS)?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 1 mm per day Explanation : Axon regeneration in the PNS typically occurs at a rate of about 1 mm per day or 1 inch/month under optimal conditions. Causes of nerve injury: Fractures and dislocations Most common cause Uncontrolled diabetes 2nd Most common cause Direct injury Cut, laceration Mechanical injury Compression Radial nerve - Saturday night palsy Axillary nerve - Dislocation of the shoulder Traction Birth injury- Erb’s palsy Ischaemic injury Volkmann’s ischaemia Toxic agents Inj. Tetracycline results in radial nerve palsy. Radiation For cancer treatment Pathogenesis of nerve injury: Nerve degeneration: Part of the neuron distal to the point of injury undergoes secondary or Wallerian degeneration. The proximal part of the injury undergoes primary or retrograde degeneration up to a single node. Nerve regeneration: Begins with the growth of the axonal stump from the proximal segment, which starts to grow distally. If the endoneurial tube (which contains Schwann cells) is intact, the axonal sprout can follow its path to reinnervate the end-organ. The rate of recovery of the axon is approximately 1 mm per day. If the endoneurial tube is interrupted, multiple sprouts (up to 100) may migrate aimlessly into the surrounding tissues (epineurium, perineurium, or adjacent tissues), forming a neuroma . Types of neuromas include: End-neuroma: Formed when the proximal and distal ends of the nerve are widely separated. Neuroma in continuity: Formed when sprouts continue to grow but do not properly reinnervate the distal end. Side-neuroma: Indicates a partial nerve cut, with sprouting forming on one side of the injury. Signs of nerve regeneration The muscle nearest to the injury site recovers first, followed by others in sequence, as the nerve reinnervates muscles from proximal to distal, known as the motor march. Tinel’s sign/ Hoffman’s sign: With progressive regeneration, Tinel sign move distally which indicates axonal regeneration and sensory restoration.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the pathology of neuropraxia?

options.A: Complete interruption of both axons and surrounding structures
options.B: Disruption of the myelin sheath with preserved axon integrity
options.C: Degeneration of the axon with intact surrounding connective tissue
options.D: Loss of the entire nerve, including the surrounding connective tissues

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Disruption of the myelin sheath with preserved axon integrity Explanation : The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components. Type Description Prognosis Neurapraxia (Grade I) Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only. No neuroma and no degeneration. Recovery is complete within 6 weeks. Axonotmesis (Grade II) Axonal damage, connective tissue intact. Neuroma in continuity. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Recovery can take up to months Complete recovery may not occur. Motor march present Neurotmesis (Grade III) Complete nerve disruption. End or side neuroma. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Spontaneous recovery never occurs. Repair is required (poor recovery) Neurapraxia: Definition Physiological disruption of conduction in nerve fibre with temporary loss of motor and sensory function without any structural damage to the nerve. Cause Commonly caused by compression, stretching, or blunt trauma to a nerve, often seen in sports injuries, falls, or prolonged pressure. Mechanism Involves disruption of the myelin sheath surrounding the nerve fibers, which leads to a temporary conduction block while preserving the axon’s structure. Symptoms Temporary numbness, weakness, or tingling in the affected area. Decreased reflexes and muscle strength, but usually not complete paralysis. Diagnosis Based on clinical examination and patient history; electrodiagnostic tests (e.g., nerve conduction studies) may confirm the diagnosis. Classification Classified as a first-degree nerve injury, indicating the least severe type of nerve injury. Prognosis Typically good, with recovery occurring within 6 weeks. Treatment Generally conservative; may include rest, physical therapy, and avoiding activities that could further irritate the nerve.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding axonotmesis?

options.A: Spontaneous recovery occurs within days or weeks
options.C: Loss of conduction within an intact neural tube
options.D: Occurs due to segmental demyelination by mechanical pressure

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Loss of conduction within an intact neural tube Explanation: The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components. Type Description Prognosis Neurapraxia (Grade I) Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only. Segmental demyelination due to mechanical pressure (Option D) No neuroma and no degeneration. Recovery is complete within days or weeks (Option A) Axonotmesis (Grade II) Axonal damage, connective tissue intact. Loss of conduction within an intact neural tube - Neuroma in continuity (Option C) Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Recovery may occur spontaneously or take many months. Complete recovery may not occur. Motor march (nerve re-innervates muscles from proximal to distal) present Neurotmesis (Grade III) Complete nerve disruption (Option B) End or side neuroma. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Spontaneous recovery never occurs. Repair is required (poor recovery) Function maybe adequate but never complete Axonotmesis: A type of nerve injury that involves damage to the axon, but the surrounding connective tissue structures (such as the epineurium, perineurium, and endoneurium) remain intact. Key Features of Axonotmesis: Axonal Damage The axon is disrupted, causing Wallerian degeneration distal to the site of injury. Intact Connective Tissues The epineurium and perineurium remain intact, which facilitates axonal regrowth. Wallerian Degeneration Occurs distal to the injury, involving degeneration of the axon and myelin sheath. Regeneration The nerve has the potential to regenerate because the pathway for axonal growth is preserved, typically at a rate of 1-3 mm per day. Crush Injuries This is a common mechanism leading to axonotmesis, where the nerve is compressed or crushed, causing axonal damage. Motor and Sensory Deficits Loss of motor function and sensation distal to the injury. Absent Reflexes Reflexes in the affected region are typically absent. Conservative Management In most cases, surgical intervention is not necessary. Recovery occurs as the axon regenerates. Physical therapy. Prognosis Good prognosis for recovery since the structural framework of the nerve is preserved, allowing for regrowth and reconnection of the nerve fibers. Recovery can take weeks to months.

questions.question: A 32-year-old man sustains a deep laceration to his forearm from a sharp object. On examination, he has complete loss of motor function and sensation in the hand, and reflexes are absent. Despite immobilization and physical therapy, no improvement is noted after several weeks. Which type of nerve injury has most likely occurred?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Neurotmesis Explanation: Neurotmesis is the most severe form of nerve injury, involving complete disruption of both the axon and the surrounding connective tissues. This results in total loss of motor and sensory function distal to the injury, as seen in this patient. The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components. Type Description Prognosis Neurapraxia (Grade I) Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only. No neuroma and no degeneration. Recovery is complete within 6 weeks. Axonotmesis (Grade II) Axonal damage, connective tissue intact. Neuroma in continuity. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Recovery may occur spontaneously or take many months. Complete recovery may not occur Neurotmesis (Grade III) Complete nerve disruption. End or side neuroma. Degeneration: Proximally+distally. Complete recovery never occurs Neurotmesis: The most severe form of nerve injury is characterized by the complete severance of the nerve, including both the axon and the surrounding connective tissues. This results in a total loss of nerve function distal to the site of injury, with both motor and sensory deficits. Key features Complete Disruption: Both the axon and the nerve's supportive structures are completely severed. Loss of Function: This leads to total loss of motor and sensory function in the region supplied by the affected nerve. Wallerian Degeneration: The portion of the axon distal to the injury undergoes Wallerian degeneration, where the axon and myelin sheath break down. Common Causes Severe Trauma: Penetrating injuries such as cuts, gunshot wounds, or severe crush injuries are common causes. Clinical Presentation Complete Motor and Sensory Loss: There is no movement or sensation distal to the injury. Reflexes in the affected area are absent. No Spontaneous Recovery: Unlike less severe nerve injuries, neurotmesis does not allow for spontaneous recovery because the nerve's structural continuity is disrupted. Diagnosis Clinical Examination Electromyography (EMG) and Nerve Conduction Studies (NCS) MRI or ultrasound Treatment Surgical Repair: Nerve ends are surgically reconnected, or nerve grafting is performed to bridge the gap between the severed ends. Tendon transfer procedures are also done. Physical Therapy: Post-surgical therapy is crucial to maintain muscle tone and promote recovery once the nerve starts regenerating. Prognosis Without Surgical Repair: The prognosis is poor, with no chance of functional recovery. With Surgical Repair: Recovery depends on the extent of the injury, the length of time between injury and surgery, and the success of the repair. Even with surgery, full recovery may not be possible, especially in cases of long nerve gaps or severe trauma. questions.question: Focal segmental demyelination of a nerve is classified under Neurapraxia in the Seddon classification. What is the grade of the nerve injury according to the Sunderland classification?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Grade I Explanation: Classification of nerve injury: Sunderland classification Seddon classification Injury Management Grade I (Option A) Neurapraxia Focal segmental demyelination Spontaneous Recovery Grade II (Option B ruled out) Axonotmesis Damaged axon with intact endoneurium Spontaneous Recovery Grade III (Option C ruled out) Axonotmesis Damaged axon and endoneurium with intact perineurium Surgical intervention may be needed Grade IV (option D ruled out ) Axonotmesis Only the epineurium is intact. The nerve trunk is still in continuity but internal damage is severe the injured segment should be excised and the nerve repaired or grafted Grade V Neurotemesis The nerve is divided Nerve repairment

questions.question: Grade IV nerve injury according to Sunderland classification corresponds to which Seddon classification?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Axonotmesis Explanation: Sunderland classification Seddon classification Injury Management Grade IV Axonotmesis (Option A) Damaged axon, endoneurium, and perineurium with intact epineurium Surgery Grade V Neurotmesis (Option B ruled out) Complete nerve transection (disruption of myelin sheath, axon, endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium) Surgery Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page 282 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557746/figure/article-25766.image.f1/

questions.question: Which of the following best describes external neurolysis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Freeing nerve from surrounding Explanation: External neurolysis is the process of freeing nerves from the surrounding scar tissue Management of nerve injury: Conservative Treatment Required in all types of nerve injury Aimed at preserving limb mobility during nerve recovery Types: Splintage of the Paralysed Limb Preserve Joint Mobility Skin and Nail Care Physiotherapy Pain Relief Operative Treatment Nerve Suture Techniques include epineural, epi-perineural, perineural, and group fascicular repair. Methods for achieving an end-to-end suture: Mobilization, joint positioning, nerve course alteration, stripping branches, and sacrificing unimportant branches. Nerve Grafting For gaps greater than 10 cm or when tension is likely at the suture line. The sural nerve is used as a graft. Neurolysis External Neurolysis: Freeing nerve from surrounding scar tissue. (Option A) Internal Neurolysis: Dissecting nerve sheath to relieve internal pressure. (Option B ruled out) Reconstructive Surgery When there’s no hope of nerve recovery Usually after 18 months Types: Tendon transfers Arthrodesis Muscle transfer Reference: Apley and Solomon’s System of Orthopedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Pages 284-286 Campbell textbook of orthopedics, 14th edition, Pages 3288-3294

questions.question: What is the location at which the radial nerve is getting injured in a Saturday night palsy?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Spiral groove Explanation: Saturday night palsy - compression of the radial nerve between the radio-spiral groove and the lateral intermuscular septum Radial nerve course and branches: Location Causes of radial nerve injury In the Axilla Aneurysm of the axillary vessels Crutch palsy In the Shoulder Proximal humeral fractures Shoulder dislocation In the Spiral Groove (5 ‘S’) (Option D) Shaft fracture Saturday night palsy Syringe palsy Surgical positions (Trendelenburg) 'S’march's (Esmarch) tourniquet palsy Between Spiral Groove and Lateral Epicondyle Fracture shaft of humerus Supracondylar fracture humerus Lateral epicondyle fracture Penetrating and gunshot injuries Cubitus valgus deformity At the Elbow Posterior dislocation of the elbow Fracture of the head of the radius Monteggia fractures In the Forearm Fracture of both bones in the forearm Penetrating and gunshot injuries

questions.question: A 7-year-old boy falls off the monkey bars, landing on his outstretched hand, and immediately experiences severe pain and swelling around his elbow. An X-ray reveals a supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Which of the following features will not be seen if his radial nerve is injured?

options.A: Loss of extension of metacarpophalangeal joints

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Absence of triceps reflex Explanation: The absence of triceps reflex is seen in the injury of the radial nerve around the shoulder joint, not the elbow joint. Radial nerve lesions: Type Injury Clinical Features Low Lesions Fractures or dislocations at the elbow Cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joints (Option A ruled out) Thumb weakness (Option C ruled out) Radial deviation of the wrist (Option B ruled out) High Lesions Humerus fractures or prolonged tourniquet pressure Wrist drop Inability to extend MCP joints or elevate thumb Sensory loss around the anatomical snuffbox Very High Lesions Around the shoulder Weakness of wrist and hand Paralysis of triceps and absence of triceps reflex (Option D) Type of Injury Treatment Open Injuries Immediate exploration and nerve repair or grafting Closed Injuries Wait 12 weeks for recovery before exploring Use EMG if no improvement; if denervation is detected, perform nerve exploration and repair or grafting Fractures of Humerus Assess for nerve injury on admission If the injury appears post-manipulation or internal fixation, explore and repair or graft immediately Recovery Management Perform passive hand movements Splint the wrist in extension-cock up splint: Avoid ‘lively’ hand splints to prevent metacarpophalangeal joint contractures Long-term Disability Use tendon transfers: pronator teres to short radial extensor, flexor carpi radialis or ulnaris to finger extensors, palmaris longus to thumb abductor

questions.question: Following RTA, a young male presented with swelling over his elbow. X-ray revealed the following. Which of the following statements is true about the origin of the most likely nerve affected?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) C8-T1 Explanation: The X-ray shows a medial epicondyle fracture of the humerus . The most common nerve affected in this fracture is the ulnar nerve (root value: C8-T1) . Root values: Radial nerve: C5-T1 Median nerve: C5-C7 (lateral root) ; C8-T1 (medial root) Ulnar nerve: C8-T1 Anatomy and causes of ulnar nerve injury: The course of ulnar nerve: Muscles supplied: Forearm: Flexor carpi ulnaris and medial ½ of flexor digitorum profundus High ulnar paradox- In high lesions of the ulnar nerve (occur with elbow fractures or dislocations) the hand is not markedly deformed because the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.question: All of the following are tests done to test the nerve shown in the image except A. B. C. D.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Explanation: The marked structure in the dissection image is the Ulnar nerve . All the tests given in the options are used to test the function of the ulnar nerve except for Option B - Pen test (used for testing the Median nerve ). Tests for Ulnar nerve: Test Action & Muscle tested Froment’s sign: (Option A) Action tested: Adduction of the thumb Muscles: Palmar interossei, Adductor pollici s. Compensation: In ulnar nerve injury, to hold the paper, the patient uses Flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve ) - which is responsible for the ‘P sign’ (or) ‘Froment sign’. Card test: (Option D) Action tested: Adduction of fingers Muscle: Palmar interossei Egawa test: (Option C) Action tested: Abduction of fingers Muscle: Dorsal interossei Pen test (Option B) : Action tested: Abduction of thumb Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis Nerve supply: Median nerve

questions.question: The patient presents to you with the following deformity as shown. Which is the ideal procedure of choice to correct this deformity?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Modified Bunnel’s operation Explanation: The deformity shown in the image is a partial claw hand - seen in ulnar nerve injury. Modified Bunnel’s operation is the procedure of choice for ulnar claw hand. Deformities in ulnar nerve injury: Partial claw hand: Clawing: Hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of interphalangeal joints. Clawing is seen in 2 medial fingers only. Seen in pure ulnar nerve injury . Also known as the true claw hand. Complete claw hand: Clawing of all 4 fingers. Seen in combined median + ulnar nerve palsy Tardy ulnar nerve palsy: Slow-onset (over years) ulnar nerve palsy. Seen with cubitus valgus deformity seen in lateral epicondyle humerus fracture. Other deformities: Wasting of hypothenar muscles & intrinsic muscles of the hand. Hollow inter-metacarpal spaces in hand. A) Ulnar clawing;

questions.question: The child presented with swelling around the elbow joint following a fall over an outstretched hand. X-ray elbow AP & Lateral views are given below. Which among the following is true regarding the most likely nerve injured in this case?

options.A: Descends adjacent to radial artery in the forearm
options.C: Gives motor branches in the arm
options.D: Supplies lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Supplies lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus Explanation: In the case of a supracondylar fracture humerus , the most likely nerve injured is the Anterior interosseous nerve - a branch of the Median nerve . The anterior interosseous nerve is a motor branch of the Median nerve that supplies all flexors of the forearm except for flexor carpi ulnaris & medial ½ of flexor digitorum profundus. Median nerve - anatomy and causes of injury: Course and anatomy: Muscles supplied: Arm: none (Option C) Forearm: All flexor muscles except Flexor carpi ulnaris and medial ½ of flexor digitorum profundus (supplied by ulnar nerve) (Option D) Hand: Thenar muscles: Abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis 1st and 2nd lumbricals (Option B) Causes of injury: Arm: Tight tourniquet (most common, causes neuropraxia), Humerus fracture Elbow: Supracondylar fracture, Posterior dislocation of elbow. Wrist: Carpal tunnel syndrome

questions.question: The clinician performed the following test as shown. Which muscle is being tested here?

options.D: Lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Abductor pollicis brevis Explanation: The clinical test done is the Pen test which tests the Abductor pollicis brevis - supplied by Median nerve. Adductor pollicis (Option A) : Supplied by ulnar nerve. Book test/Froment sign is done. Flexor carpi radialis (Option B) : Supplied by median nerve. Lateral ½ of flexor digitorum profundus (Option D) : Supplied by median nerve. Along with Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus does flexion of fingers. Injury to the median nerve will cause a Pointing index sign on Oschner clasp/Benediction test. Clinical tests for Median nerve: Test Muscle tested and action Pen test: Muscle: Abductor pollicis brevis (Option C) Action: Abduction of thumb Oschner clasp test: Muscle: Flexor digitorum superficialis & flexor digitorum profundus Action: Flexion of lateral 2 digits Pointing index sign seen. Thumb opposition: Muscle: Opponens pollcis Action: Opposition of thumb O-sign is seen in normal patients Treatment of median nerve palsy: Conservative management mainly. If not recovered, nerve repair is done by High median nerve palsy (above elbow): 9 months Low median nerve palsy (distal forearm): 12 months
